I'm debating on the negative team on this issue:
 
 Resolved: that the US Federal government should adopt a policy to substantially increase regulation of genetic engineering.
 
 Now my argument lies around these factors:
 
 There is no need to increase government regulation
 --There is enough regulation (ie FDA USDA EPA)
 --the word substantially means "a godo amount" to what extent do you want increase?
 --GE is a young science (30 years), how can there be current regulation when there MAY be risk factors but not definite ones.
 --GE holds a lot of promise (we have to prove this) with such an early regulation, it will screw things up; thus, GE practice and experimentation must continue for both scientists and consumers to view the effects
 --Example (of holding promise) AGRICULTURE and the regulation of GE by the EPA
 --Biotech takes care of pests and is a great promise for farmers, humans, and economy in general (not sure if I will use statement of economy)
 
 Are these arguments logical? And if they are. does anyone have any more ideas to argue against the resolved issue?

Hey, you posted that on lddebate.org too!
 
 No help, just thought I'd point it out.

title: 4Forums.com Political Debates and Polls -  GENETIC ENGINEERING...increase regualtion?
